description: In the Coverdale Bible in 1535, in Genesis and Exodus about 1250 as Middle English sunnesine; synchronically sun +â€Ž shine.

entries.meaning: (chiefly US) Open to and permitting public access, especially with regard to activities that were previously closed-door or back-room meetings.
examples: Because of the sunshine law, we could go to the planning meeting.

entries.meaning: The direct rays, light or warmth of the sun.
examples: We were warmed by the bright sunshine.

entries.meaning: A location on which the sun's rays fall.
examples: We moved out of the shade and into the sunshine.
I enjoyed the sunshine of her smile.

entries.meaning: A source of cheerfulness or joy.
The effect which the sun has when it lights and warms some place.
(UK) Friendly form of address often reserved for juniors.
examples: Alright sunshine, safe to cross now.

entries.meaning: (UK) Ironic form of address used to an inferior or troublemaker.
examples: OK, sunshine, listen up and listen good. There's five vandalised telephone boxes out there and I know you're responsible.

entries.meaning: (humorous) Used to address someone who has just woken up and/or is very sleepy.
(slang, uncountable, uncommon) Ellipsis of orange sunshine.
